para.paratext: A presumption must be based on established basic facts and not on another presumption or inference.[1]
The Georgia Supreme Court clarified Georgia law on the operation and effect of presumptions in civil cases in a unanimous 1988 decision, Miller v. Miller.[2] The court explained:

Concerning the effect of a presumption on the burden of proof, the rule, generally, is that while a presumption operating in favor of the party having the ultimate burden of persuasion requires the opposing party to go forward with evidence rebutting the presumption, it does not shift the original burden of persuasion. That burden remains with the party upon whom it was originally cast.[3]

Miller involved the rebuttable presumption of the legitimacy of a child born in wedlock. The trial court charged the jury that “the effect of these pleadings is to put the burden of proof upon the plaintiff to prove her case by a preponderance of the evidence. Now, in the answer of the defendant where he denies it's his child, the burden is on him to prove that it is not his child, and that is the same burden and preponderance of the evidence.”[4] The Georgia Supreme Court held that this charge was error and reasoned that the burden of proof lies with the person seeking to establish any fact that is essential to his case and “where a party has the burden of proof to establish a fact by the preponderance of the evidence it remains on him throughout the trial unless the defendant admits a prima facie case by the plaintiff.”[5]

In Miller, the wife obtained the benefit of the presumption by showing that the parties were married at the time of the child's birth. Although this shifted the burden of producing evidence rebutting the presumption to the husband, it did not shift the burden of persuasion to him.[6]

Miller clarified that (1) “[r]egardless of how much counter evidence the opponent has presented to rebut the presumed fact, the presumption remains alive through jury instruction and can only disappear if the jury decides to discount it,”[7] (2) rebuttable presumptions do not shift the burden of persuasion, but the burden of persuasion “remains with the party upon whom it was originally cast,”[8] and (3) rebuttable presumptions do place the burden of producing evidence on the party who has the burden of persuasion. If that burden is met, the burden of producing evidence rebutting the presumption does shift to the opposing party.[9]

Because the jury determines if a rebuttable presumption has been rebutted, the court should instruct the jury on the existence of the presumption.[10] Under Georgia law, a presumption against a party who also bears the burden of persuasion may support judgment in favor of the opposing party.

In Bennett v. Associated Food Stores,[11] the plaintiff sued for lost profits based upon the defendant's failure to make lease payments on rented vehicles. However, the plaintiff was unable to show the exact amount of his lost profits because he had destroyed his maintenance records on the leased vehicles prior to trial. The trial court directed a verdict for the defendant based upon the general rule that spoliation of evidence raises a presumption against the spoliator. The Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the directed verdict and stated that the presumption which arose from plaintiff's destruction of the maintenance records was that they would have shown no lost profits. Therefore, the presumption supported a directed verdict against the plaintiff in the absence of any evidence produced by the defendant.

Similarly, in a medical malpractice case, Hawkins v. Greenberg,[12] the plaintiff moved for a directed verdict against the physician defendant who did not rebut the testimony of plaintiff's experts. The Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the trial court's denial of the directed verdict and stated “the presumption in favor of the physician's use of due care and skill, coupled with the … rationale that a plaintiff's motion for summary judgment cannot be sustained purely on the basis of opinion evidence in a malpractice action, mandates the submission of the controlling issue to the jury even where the defendant fails to meet his evidentiary burden.”[13]

Although O.C.G.A. § 24-14-20 expressly directs that “presumptions of fact are exclusively questions for the jury,”[14] Miller did not distinguish between presumptions of fact and presumptions of law. Neither do prior Georgia cases make this distinction when discussing the operation and effect of rebuttable presumptions. Therefore, the Miller approach should apply equally to rebuttable presumptions, regardless of whether these presumptions are presumptions of fact or presumptions of law. However, Miller has no application to conclusive presumptions of law since such presumptions are not evidentiary rules but, rather, statements of substantive law.[15]

In criminal cases, it should be kept in mind that any presumption against a defendant may be limited by constitutional considerations.[16] Courts avoid the word “presumption” in criminal cases when instructing the jury regarding matters beneficial to the state's case and instead tell the jury to “infer” certain matters.[17] The Georgia Supreme Court has also disapproved a charge that “the law presumes” except for the presumption of sanity, though using the phrase may not automatically require a reversal of a conviction.[18]
Fed. R. Evid. 301 controls the operation and effect of presumptions in federal civil cases. The rule provides:

In all civil actions and proceedings not otherwise provided for by Act of Congress or by these rules, a presumption imposes on the party against whom it is directed the burden of going forward with evidence to rebut or meet the presumption, but does not shift to such party the burden of proof in the sense of the risk of nonpersuasion, which remains throughout the trial upon the party on whom it was originally cast.

Thus, in federal court, presumptions are not evidence, and the court should not charge the jury on presumptions.[19] In federal practice, “[t]he opponent of a presumption may negate the procedural effect of a presumption by introducing enough evidence so that a reasonable juror could find the non-existence of the presumed fact. … If the opponent meets this burden, the presumption disappears from the case. … If the opponent fails to meet this burden, the fact-finder must find that the presumed fact exists.”[20] Like in Georgia, the presumption merely shifts the burden of production, not the burden of persuasion to the defendant.[21] “The ultimate burden of persuading the trier of fact … remains at all times with the plaintiff.”[22] The Georgia rule regarding presumptions applies in civil actions and proceedings in which Georgia law applies.[23]

The court's analysis in Miller is “confined to a civil case and assumes the presumption is rebuttable, as opposed to conclusive, and favors the party having the original burden of proof. Presumptions operating against such a party would affect neither the duty to produce evidence nor the burden of proof.” Miller v. Miller, 258 Ga. 168, 169 n.2, 366 S.E.2d 682 (1988).

The opinion also stated that it would seem helpful to acquaint the jury with effect of the presumption or, at least, with the effect of proof of the fact which gives rise to the presumption. Thus, the jury might be instructed about whether the presumption affects the burden of producing evidence, which depends on who has the burden of persuasion. The jury might also be instructed that proof of a fact giving rise to a presumption does not change the burden of persuasion.

Nor should the Miller approach be applied to the presumption of negligence against transit companies. The United States Supreme Court has ruled that this type of presumption violates the Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution if the presumption does not disappear upon the introduction of rebutting evidence. Western & A.R.R. v. Henderson, 279 U.S. 639, 49 S. Ct. 445, 73 L. Ed. 884 (1929). Georgia cases have held that the U.S. Supreme Court's analysis applies to Georgia's negligence presumption against transit companies. Seaboard Coast Line R. Co. v. Wroblewski, 138 Ga. App. 793, 227 S.E.2d 438 (1976).

Some legal scholars have argued that Federal Rule 301 does not preclude instructions that at least alert the jury to the strength of logic and policy underlying a presumption, even though evidence contrary to the existence of the presumed fact has been introduced …. Furthermore, there has been willingness on the part of the federal courts to find that certain acts of Congress create presumptions of greater vitality than that provided by Rule 301 … or even that certain presumptions in existence at the time of the adoption of Rule 301 are not subject to the procedure set forth in that rule.
